message_2:
To determine whether a subset is open, closed, or neither, we need to look at the topology T and the definition of open and closed sets.

A set is open if it is an element of the topology T. A set is closed if its complement (with respect to the space X) is open.

Let's analyze each subset:

A = {a}
A is open since it is an element of the topology T. Its complement is X - A = {b, c}, which is not open, so A is not closed. Therefore, A is open.

B = {b}
B is not an element of T, so it is not open. Its complement is X - B = {a, c}, which is also not an element of T, so B is not closed either. Therefore, B is neither open nor closed.

C = {a, b}
C is not an element of T, so it is not open. Its complement is X - C = {c}, which is not an element of T, so C is not closed either. Therefore, C is neither open nor closed.

D = {a, c}
D is not an element of T, so it is not open. Its complement is X - D = {b}, which is not an element of T, so D is not closed either. Therefore, D is neither open nor closed.

E = {b, c}
E is not an element of T, so it is not open. Its complement is X - E = {a}, which is an element of T, so E is closed. Therefore, E is closed.

F = {a, b}
F is not an element of T, so it is not open. Its complement is X - F = {c}, which is not an element of T, so F is not closed either. Therefore, F is neither open nor closed.

In summary:
A: open
B: neither open nor closed
C: neither open nor closed
D: neither open nor closed
E: closed
F: neither open nor closed
